doc.title: phylip

description.text: PHYLIP is a package of programs for inferring phylogenies.

doc.reference: Felsenstein, J. 1993. PHYLIP (Phylogeny Inference Package) version 3.5c. Distributed by the author. Department of Genetics, University of Washington, Seattle.
Felsenstein, J. 1989. PHYLIP -- Phylogeny Inference Package (Version 3.2). Cladistics 5: 164-166.

description.text: Compute distance matrix from protein sequences

comment.text: This program uses protein sequences to compute a distance matrix, under four different models of amino acid replacement. It can also compute a table of similarity between the amino acid sequences.
The distance for each pair of species estimates the total branch length between the two species, and can be used in the distance matrix programs FITCH, KITSCH or NEIGHBOR.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The input file must contained aligned sequences in PHYLIP format obtained by sequence alignment programs.
xhtml:div.div:
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
5 13 Alpha AACGTGGCCACAT Beta AAGGTCGCCACAC Gamma CAGTTCGCCACAA Delta GAGATTTCCGCCT Epsilon GAGATCTCCGCCC

div.pre: 5 13 Alpha AACGTGGCCACAT Beta AAGGTCGCCACAC Gamma CAGTTCGCCACAA Delta GAGATTTCCGCCT Epsilon GAGATCTCCGCCC

interface.label: Distance model (P) Jones-Taylor-Thornton matrix Henikoff/Tillier PMB matrix Dayhoff PAM matrix Kimura formula Similarity table Categories model

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

interface.label: Gamma distribution of rates among positions (G) No Yes Gamma+Invariant

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

interface.label:
Coefficient of variation of substitution rate among positions (must be positive)?
Instead of the more widely-known coefficient alpha, PROTDIST uses the coefficient of variation (ratio of the standard deviation to the mean) of rates among amino acid positions. So if there is 20% variation in rates, the CV is is 0.20. The square of the C.V. is also the reciprocal of the better-known shape parameter, alpha, of the Gamma distribution, so in this case the shape parameter alpha = 1/(0.20*0.20) = 25. If you want to achieve a particular value of alpha, such as 10, you will want to use a CV of 1/sqrt(100) = 1/10 = 0.1.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

interface.label: Fraction of invariant positions

xhtml:div.label:
Perform a bootstrap before analysis?
Yes No
By selecting this option, the bootstrap will be performed on your sequence file. So you don't need to perform a separated seqboot before.
Don't give an already bootstrapped file to the program, this won't work!

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Resampling methods (J)?
Bootstrap Delete-half jackknife Permute species for each character Permute character order Permute within species
1. The bootstrap. Bootstrapping was invented by Bradley Efron in 1979, and its use in phylogeny estimation was introduced by me (Felsenstein, 1985b). It involves creating a new data set by sampling N characters randomly with replacement, so that the resulting data set has the same size as the original, but some characters have been left out and others are duplicated. The random variation of the results from analyzing these bootstrapped data sets can be shown statistically to be typical of the variation that you would get from collecting new data sets. The method assumes that the characters evolve independently, an assumption that may not be realistic for many kinds of data.
2. Delete-half-jackknifing. This alternative to the bootstrap involves sampling a random half of the characters, and including them in the data but dropping the others. The resulting data sets are half the size of the original, and no characters are duplicated. The random variation from doing this should be very similar to that obtained from the bootstrap. The method is advocated by Wu (1986).
3. Permuting species for each characters. This method of resampling (well, OK, it may not be best to call it resampling) was introduced by Archie (1989) and Faith (1990; see also Faith and Cranston, 1991). It involves permuting the columns of the data matrix separately. This produces data matrices that have the same number and kinds of characters but no taxonomic structure. It is used for different purposes than the bootstrap, as it tests not the variation around an estimated tree but the hypothesis that there is no taxonomic structure in the data: if a statistic such as number of steps is significantly smaller in the actual data than it is in replicates that are permuted, then we can argue that there is some taxonomic structure in the data (though perhaps it might be just the presence of aa pair of sibling species).
4. Permuting characters order. This simply permutes the order of the characters, the same reordering being applied to all species. For many methods of tree inference this will make no difference to the outcome (unless one has rates of evolution correlated among adjacent sites). It is included as a possible step in carrying out a permutation test of homogeneity of characters (such as the Incongruence Length Difference test).
5. Permuting characters separately for each species. This is a method introduced by Steel, Lockhart, and Penny (1993) to permute data so as to destroy all phylogenetic structure, while keeping the base composition of each species the same as before. It shuffles the character order separately for each species.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Random number seed (must be odd)
How many replicates (R)?
Use weights for sites (W) Yes No

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Print out the data at start of run (1) Yes No

fieldset.legend: Categories model options (options available only if Categories model choosed)

xhtml:div.label: Genetic code (U) Universal (U) Mitochondrial (M) Vertebrate mitochondrial (V) Fly mitochondrial (F) Yeast mitochondrial (Y)

Categorization of amino acids (A)?
George/Hunt/Barker (G) Chemical (C) Hall (H)
All have groups: (Glu Gln Asp Asn), (Lys Arg His), (Phe Tyr Trp) plus:
George/Hunt/Barker: (Cys), (Met Val Leu Ileu), (Gly Ala Ser Thr Pro)
Chemical: (Cys Met), (Val Leu Ileu Gly Ala Ser Thr), (Pro)
Hall: (Cys), (Met Val Leu Ileu), (Gly Ala Ser Thr), (Pro)
Prob change category (1.0=easy) (E)

Transition/transversion ratio (T)?
If the Categories distance is selected another menu option, T, will appear allowing the user to supply the Transition/Transversion ratio that should be assumed at the underlying DNA level. The transition/transversion ratio can be any number from 0.5 upwards.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The input file must contained aligned sequences in PHYLIP format obtained by sequence alignment programs.

So if there is 20% variation in rates, the CV is is 0.20. The square of the C.V. is also the reciprocal of the better-known shape parameter, alpha, of the Gamma distribution, so in this case the shape parameter alpha = 1/(0.20*0.20) = 25. If you want to achieve a particular value of alpha, such as 10, you will want to use a CV of 1/sqrt(100) = 1/10 = 0.1.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: 1. The bootstrap. Bootstrapping was invented by Bradley Efron in 1979, and its use in phylogeny estimation was introduced by me (Felsenstein, 1985b). It involves creating a new data set by sampling N characters randomly with replacement, so that the resulting data set has the same size as the original, but some characters have been left out and others are duplicated. The random variation of the results from analyzing these bootstrapped data sets can be shown statistically to be typical of the variation that you would get from collecting new data sets. The method assumes that the characters evolve independently, an assumption that may not be realistic for many kinds of data.

2. Delete-half-jackknifing. This alternative to the bootstrap involves sampling a random half of the characters, and including them in the data but dropping the others. The resulting data sets are half the size of the original, and no characters are duplicated. The random variation from doing this should be very similar to that obtained from the bootstrap. The method is advocated by Wu (1986).

3. Permuting species for each characters. This method of resampling (well, OK, it may not be best to call it resampling) was introduced by Archie (1989) and Faith (1990; see also Faith and Cranston, 1991). It involves permuting the columns of the data matrix separately. This produces data matrices that have the same number and kinds of characters but no taxonomic structure. It is used for different purposes than the bootstrap, as it tests not the variation around an estimated tree but the hypothesis that there is no taxonomic structure in the data: if a statistic such as number of steps is significantly smaller in the actual data than it is in replicates that are permuted, then we can argue that there is some taxonomic structure in the data (though perhaps it might be just the presence of aa pair of sibling species).

4. Permuting characters order. This simply permutes the order of the characters, the same reordering being applied to all species. For many methods of tree inference this will make no difference to the outcome (unless one has rates of evolution correlated among adjacent sites). It is included as a possible step in carrying out a permutation test of homogeneity of characters (such as the Incongruence Length Difference test).

5. Permuting characters separately for each species. This is a method introduced by Steel, Lockhart, and Penny (1993) to permute data so as to destroy all phylogenetic structure, while keeping the base composition of each species the same as before. It shuffles the character order separately for each species.

format.code: ($value) ? "seqboot < seqboot.params && mv outfile seqboot.outfile && rm infile && ln -s seqboot.outfile infile && " : ""

comment.text: 1. The bootstrap. Bootstrapping was invented by Bradley Efron in 1979, and its use in phylogeny estimation was introduced by me (Felsenstein, 1985b). It involves creating a new data set by sampling N characters randomly with replacement, so that the resulting data set has the same size as the original, but some characters have been left out and others are duplicated. The random variation of the results from analyzing these bootstrapped data sets can be shown statistically to be typical of the variation that you would get from collecting new data sets. The method assumes that the characters evolve independently, an assumption that may not be realistic for many kinds of data.

2. Delete-half-jackknifing. This alternative to the bootstrap involves sampling a random half of the characters, and including them in the data but dropping the others. The resulting data sets are half the size of the original, and no characters are duplicated. The random variation from doing this should be very similar to that obtained from the bootstrap. The method is advocated by Wu (1986).

3. Permuting species for each characters. This method of resampling (well, OK, it may not be best to call it resampling) was introduced by Archie (1989) and Faith (1990; see also Faith and Cranston, 1991). It involves permuting the columns of the data matrix separately. This produces data matrices that have the same number and kinds of characters but no taxonomic structure. It is used for different purposes than the bootstrap, as it tests not the variation around an estimated tree but the hypothesis that there is no taxonomic structure in the data: if a statistic such as number of steps is significantly smaller in the actual data than it is in replicates that are permuted, then we can argue that there is some taxonomic structure in the data (though perhaps it might be just the presence of aa pair of sibling species).

4. Permuting characters order. This simply permutes the order of the characters, the same reordering being applied to all species. For many methods of tree inference this will make no difference to the outcome (unless one has rates of evolution correlated among adjacent sites). It is included as a possible step in carrying out a permutation test of homogeneity of characters (such as the Incongruence Length Difference test).

5. Permuting characters separately for each species. This is a method introduced by Steel, Lockhart, and Penny (1993) to permute data so as to destroy all phylogenetic structure, while keeping the base composition of each species the same as before. It shuffles the character order separately for each species.

Bootstrap Delete-half jackknife Permute species for each character Permute character order Permute within species

It involves creating a new data set by sampling N characters randomly with replacement, so that the resulting data set has the same size as the original, but some characters have been left out and others are duplicated. The random variation of the results from analyzing these bootstrapped data sets can be shown statistically to be typical of the variation that you would get from collecting new data sets. The method assumes that the characters evolve independently, an assumption that may not be realistic for many kinds of data.
2. Delete-half-jackknifing. This alternative to the bootstrap involves sampling a random half of the characters, and including them in the data but dropping the others. The resulting data sets are half the size of the original, and no characters are duplicated. The random variation from doing this should be very similar to that obtained from the bootstrap. The method is advocated by Wu (1986).
3. Permuting species for each characters. This method of resampling (well, OK, it may not be best to call it resampling) was introduced by Archie (1989) and Faith (1990; see also Faith and Cranston, 1991). It involves permuting the columns of the data matrix separately. This produces data matrices that have the same number and kinds of characters but no taxonomic structure. This is a method introduced by Steel, Lockhart, and Penny (1993) to permute data so as to destroy all phylogenetic structure, while keeping the base composition of each species the same as before. It shuffles the character order separately for each species.
